commentBody: About to get started on this one :)
Too quick‚Ä¶
Great puzzle, great theme, but I think this one could have benefited from trickier cluing.

I really enjoyed this! Was looking forward to a meaty AHA when I hit the purpose of the circled letters, and the puzzle delivered. 

TBH I finished quickly, but no worries, Friday and Saturday are when I expect knucklebusters. This is a great Thursday, well done.
Thursday pb!

This was good! The theme deftly concealed itself for quite a while, which deprived me of precious theme letters and seriously slowed down the solve. Once I caught on, my repeatedly forgetting that I knew the theme gimmick did not apply to Down answers seriously slowed down the solve. Which made it all the more fun. And I appreciate that the theme entries all form words or phrases. I confess to not knowing who SID, TED, ABE, SAM, and MEL are.

A weird combination of clever word play in the themed answers, and scads of pop culture general knowledge answers everywhere else, including two musicals, which seemed to rub a lot of people the wrong way in the Wicked puzzle.  Even though many of the general knowledge questions were unknown to me, they all seemed to fall into place fairly quickly.  I liked it, but I imagine there will be tons of complaints.

I liked the mini food theme with SEL, SPICERUBS, UMAMIBOMBS and ATTA.  Pretty spicy.

Here's an extraneous fun fact about this puzzle: Does anyone remember the 2006 documentary from Patrick Creadon, Wordplay. It had cameos of several well known, life long puzzle solvers, one of whom was Ken Burns. 

I recently saw an extraordinary conversation on grief between Anderson Cooper and Ken Burns. Ken was particularly open about the devastating loss of his mother when he was 11, and how his father barely coped. But he allowed Ken to stay up late and watch movies with him. When Ken was 12, he witnessed his father cry for the first time watching a movie together, and Ken said that's when he decided he would be a filmmaker. The movie they were watching: Carol Reed's Odd Man Out. I imagine Ken is doing this puzzle as usual.  I hope the unexpected appearance of that crucial film, out of context, out of nowhere, makes him smile.
Surprised AI is ok to use when creating NYT crossword puzzles.
Sigh, it seems I am odd man out again at Maison des Emus.  Look for my maybe kind of funny comment sometime tomorrow‚Ä¶

Genuinely how are you supposed to gold some of these puzzles. I can just never seem to reason out the last bit. Even with the theme and 90% filled it‚Äôs always that last bit of trivia that I can never get. It is excruciatingly painful to be so close but so far.
I thought Jabba was originally played by a human and not a large puppet.

Enjoyed this puzzle though I had to work and rework some of the answers , especially as I didn't understand the circled letters until I saw the reveal.   
@Sam Corbin, I was lost in the Sierra Madre along with you!!   BTW, nice column!

I didn't love this one.  It felt easier than I expect on Thursdays and the theme seemed too simple.  Reading the constructor comments I gain some appreciation for the task (and realized the every-other-letter part of the odd-man theme) but the end result still didn't bowl me over.  Ah well.  I expect others enjoyed it more.
Who are Sid, Ted, Abe, Sam and Mel? I think they should be in a band

@Sam

I'm a clencher, too, especially with Thursday, but really for Friday and Saturday, too.

On Friday and Saturday, I clench mostly because I fear I won't be able to find a critical mass of entries from which to branch out.  I seem to either get them cleanly or fail them miserably.

Thursdays, it's more that there'll be some trick I just can't suss out.

And always I clench that there will be one vital square (SID/DDR cross, I'll ne'er forget you) that just won't happen.

But I definitely clench...teeth, jaw, fists...you name it.

Mr. Wagner, it's really wonderful that you continue to dedicate yourself to the art part of construction. At first I thought that the ODD of ODD MAN OUT referred to the names having three letters. The elegance of having it be the placement of the names' letters is truly laudable. I also appreciate that the theme did in fact help with the solve. Once I figured one out, the others fell like dominoes. The musical accompaniment for this puzzle was, of course, ANITA Baker. Here are two songs of hers: https://youtu.be/WrfcbNCqH40?si=8taEWgPgb3EBGxM6 https://youtu.be/8lbJgOJIS_8?si=XlQGVVKDneYQnnNA Thank you, Mr. Wagner, for always bringing us great puzzles!

ODD MAN OUT was a 13 episode TV series in the late 90‚Äôs with Erik von Detten as the lone male in a house full of females with Markie Post playing his mom. Erik coincidentally played SID in TOY Story. 
When we moved to Wisconsin from California nine years ago, I planned out a two week drive with my two youngest kids who were in 4th grade and Kindergyat the time so that we could visit as many National Parks as possible along the way. One of the places we visited was Scottsbluff, NEB. It was an important landmark along the Oregon Trail and the Pony Express Trail if memory serves. 
As always, I love a good Adam Wagner construction, and this one did not disappoint.

Hmmm‚Ä¶ I got the Odd Man Out, and that the circled letters were odd, and could be removed. That both the full and depleted answers needed to be proper words.  The puzzle was about right for me.   Except‚Ä¶ I still haven‚Äôt finished. I‚Äôm struggling with 54d and 59d and the answers they cross. I‚Äôm sure inspiration will strike soon. (Not looking for answers here, btdubs).

Gooood evening! After a somewhat not-great day, it was nice to wind down with this puzzle.

Being 13 and all, I didn‚Äôt entirely get all the clues and just tried to solve the other direction. Eventually, not in my greatest time, I solved it. 
My favourite puzzles are the ones that have an element of wordplay or theme like the Defying Gravity one a few weeks ago.

Anyways hope you guys have a great night and to people in the morning, have a blessed day.‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

Ethan :)

I share your angst when it's time for a Thursday puzzle, and prepare for the worst.  I was able to complete today's puzzle but didn't figure out the theme. Once you explained it, I was frankly amazed at what it must have taken Mr. Wagner to construct it! Even his comments didn't do his accomplishment justice. Thanks. And, thanks for no $&**% rebuses!

I loved this puzzle.  The kind of puzzle where you stare at a clue for ten minutes, finally it clicks, then the letters it fills in answer five other clues in succession.

Cool theme that works well, lots of figure-outables, not so many obscure proper nouns.

I didn't have enough of the letters filled, so I thought it was ODDONEOUT
Then I assumed one of the letters in each group was different from the other two. 

It led me down a rabbit hole and I had to eventually look at the article for help. 

I'm a beginner puzzle solvers and Thursdays get to me!
Fun theme, the bottom half just brutal with naticks and difficult solves.

I had ODD ONE OUT for the longest time.  So while I figured out the circled letters had to be dropped, I could not for the life of me understand why!   Finally, with just a few letters to go, used Autocheck and then it all made sense and could finish!   Umami bomb was a fun one

Been going through the archives and enjoying how challenging Thursdays-Sundays used to be pre-2020. Tricky, clever clues and fill that assumed solvers were familiar with literally anything other than A-list celebrities and the most current possible events/vocabulary. Sad to see what it's turned into
the ice between clever and "seriously?" (e.g. odd-letter placement) can get dangerously thin of a thursday...

I solved the puzzle by letting the crosses do it for me.  I'm not up to puzzling out a theme, so just let the fills get odd and it was done.  Two pop look-ups, but the rest just fell into place.  I'm currently under the care of 5 different doctors, so not up to any heavy duty thinking. (I'll just have to RIDE it out and hope for BETTERDAYS.)

He looked for something to SOP up his sauce and ALIT upon some bread made from ATTA flour and SPICERUBS. ‚ÄúEUREKA!‚Äù, he cried. However this set off an UMAMIBOMB. ‚ÄúEGADS! HEY, JOKESONME‚Äù, quoth he!

I tried to guess who these men were. Maybe the 1919 white Sox? Odd man out maybe a baseball clue? (No, they aren't) Are they just random names? 
I tried to connect the names we removed from the across words but they seem to have no connection. What does ambient have to do with Mint. What does Abe have to do with Mint?
So I'm disappointed in that, unless I'm really missing something. The wordplay article doesn't say.

I don‚Äôt clench on Thursdays. I feel a tingle of anticipation and hope for a challenge. This one‚Ä¶ kind of delivered? I figured out the trick pretty quickly, so there was no ‚Äúwow‚Äù moment. But I didn‚Äôt not enjoy it, so I can‚Äôt complain. 

I do appreciate the constructor notes about AI. When used correctly, it can be a great tool. When used incorrectly (as it will be), it could be the downfall of all of us. I‚Äôm very leery about our AI future, but I try to be hopeful. Maybe we‚Äôll get lucky and the emus will stop snacking on our comments and eat AI instead.
Cute: ‚ÄúEsters‚Äù across from ‚ÄúEstee!‚Äù

Other than that, a fun romp.

That was delightful!

I thought SPICE RUBS and AVRIL were clever clues. I know constructing a theme is very difficult, and I couldn't do it, but my preference is for interesting, thought-provoking clues.

I liked how figuring out TURN ON required saying it with the proper stress pattern. Took me a while.

(Reminds me of the old joke "She was turned on by the television...and vice-versa." Ian Anderson of Jethro Tull included this in his patter, at a circa-1970 Carnegie Hall concert.)
There is a fine line between clever and too cute. Ambient and better days crossed it.

Random thoughts: 

‚Ä¢	Much schwa di vivre in answer endings ‚Äì ULTRA, SARA, JABBA, DEBRA, EVITA, EUREKA, ANITA, ATTA.
‚Ä¢	Love UMAMI BOMB, though I‚Äôve never heard it in the wild.
‚Ä¢	My favorite NYT answer debuts ‚Äì and there were six ‚Äì are JOKES ON ME and BITING WIT.  I‚Äôm amazed that these terrific answers have never appeared before.
‚Ä¢	For a while, as I was solving, I wondered if the three-letter theme names all belonged to some famous group of stars from the past, like the Rat Pack.
‚Ä¢	I like the behemoth JABBA sitting atop the revealer, pressing that ODD MAN OUT.
‚Ä¢	AMBIENT evokes crossword stalwart Eno.
‚Ä¢	[Place for a castle] stymied me for quite a few beats, and is a lovely original clue for an answer that has appeared nearly 60 times in the major crossword outlets.

So, lovely little side trips for me on top of your clever concept, Adam.  Thank you for this!

A puzzle that struck me as expertly crafted and yet not much fun to solve. More of a Wednesday puzzle thematically, and jam-packed with names. Solved it unaided, but took more than 20 minutes, most of it spent in the E and NE.

Of course, the 3-letter male names were thematic, but quite the collection of additional proper names in the grid. Interestingly, and perhaps by design, almost all the non-thematic names were female names---with AARONBURR, MRT and (perhaps) JABBA being the exceptions.

Other than BRA appearing both in the SW corner (in DEBRA) and also in the SE, the grid seems outstanding. Just wish I had enjoyed solving the puzzle a bit more than I did, but perhaps that's on me.

I really enjoyed today. The moment when the penny dropped on the theme is a big part of why I love the NYT crosswords. Thought the difficulty was right on for a Thursday as well!

Mars follower, in Marseille

A slower than average one for me. Too much general knowledge of the sort I did not know. I Don't know Rihanna's songs but might have solved the clue from crossers if her full stage name were used. Not with this abbreviation. Presumably, I'll eventually learn the names of the larger islands of Hawaii, but instead I know those of the larger Channel Islands. That's the problem in doing a crossword emanating from a city I've only visited once in a country I've spent probably just over a month in. There were a few answers like MR T which I could have got if I had thought of how it might be broken down. But that's another transatlantic  cultural difference. UK crosswords tend to indicate how the answer is brtoken down into words.
Pretty boring theme for a Thursday if you ask me

This was one of my fastest times for a Thursday - about 18 minutes. I've been enjoying solving the Thursday puzzles in the archives, and I am amazed at how creative these puzzles can be, considering the constraints the constructors impose upon themselves.
Reminder that AI data centers are the reason your electricity bill is so high.

(I was also slow to find stuff I did know for sure, such as KAUAI, EVITA, PSAT/TESTS...)  

Several entries remain mysteries--EVA GREEN, RIRI, SARA of Spanx, KATEY, ANITA, NHC... actually, that's more than "several."

Sid, Ted, Abe, Sam, and Mel walked into a bar. It was a dive bar called SKIN DIVES. The place had seen BETTER DAYS - not even the STAR MAP covering up the giant stain on the ceiling could make up for the AMBIENT seediness.
Mel said to the rest: ‚ÄúYou know the owner of this place, that guy Wagner? He tells such DA(R)NED LIES about me, it really makes me feel like the ODD MAN OUT.‚Äù
To his surprise, the four others felt exactly the same.  This paradox (how could all five of them be odd man out) left them‚Ä¶in a puzzle.
My brain hurts.
On a Thursday puzzle, I neither clench my jaw nor approach it like any other day.  Instead I take a special delight!

Maybe I'm not as smart as I like to think I am, but I straight up don't understand how these clues fit with the solves.  What does "turns on" have to do with BETTERDAYS? How does ALIT connect to "come down to earth?" Usually when I can't figure out a solve, seeing it makes me go "oooh" but with this puzzle it just left me more confused.
Getting KAUAI and lAnAI mixed up was my biggest challenge. Ay, yai, yai! Nice one. Give me a chance to plug a favorite blogger: https://oddmanout215.com/author/oddmanout215/

UMAMI BOMB? Huh, never would have gotten that without "explosion" in the clue. Does it come in a SPICE RUB? I bet that would be great on pork chops.

An enjoyable Thursday! Now, there's something I rarely say! Yes, I'm a "clenched," but that doesn't stop me from jumping in. Glad I stuck with it, but today's calendar is free, so it was worthwhile. 

I like to learn something new every day, and the puzzle usually is where that starts. Today was no exception. The task at hand, now is to retain what I've learned. 

If, in my grandchildren's presence, I mention that I learned "6 or 7 new things today," do you know what they will say? In unison? "Six, sevennnnnn!" I was glad to be able to do it with them the first time, thanks to an article in the NYT telling me what it was all about. No slacking grandma here! (It means nothing. Just this year's kids being kids.)

Just tucking it away for a puzzle in a year or two about adolescent slang.

Well actually, George Lucas originally originally tried to cast an authentic Hutt to play Jabba but unsurprisingly they were all too danged sexy for what he was going for. 

Given the near impossibility of the task, I think he did a decent job toning down the ineluctable desirability of the Hutts.

Honestly, who amongst us has never said or thought "Egads, Jabba is ultra creepy and slimy, but in a good way"?
My new Thursday best at 10:59
Didn't figure out the sting in this puzzle until I finished it, but fairly easily completed on the crosses. Some nice clues in there!

I enjoyed this one so, thank you, Adam, for stretching my brain so I would not be the "ODD GAL OUT" today. I muffed up the SW corner for a while when I was certain that 49D was "monde" and then realized I was not keeping my languages in alignment! I then moved from my planetary thinking to the months and the promise of spring -- AVRIL seems like such a long way off right now!

Happy Thursday, everyone!

After going through the crosses I had a lot of blank space, but the downs were very forgiving and it ended up a quick solve.

Favorite clue was about the flavor explosion. Don't think I had heard the term, but instantly knew what it had to be. @Andrzej, when I think UMAMI, I don't think salt. I think butter. 

Two days ago I made ghee with unsalted butter, cooking it until it was slightly browned, and now I'm swimming in umami.
In the past two days, we had divisive words and phrases like REUNE, MINOR TEAM, KAYO, etc. it was refreshing to have a puzzle where not a single problematic word stuck out like a sore thumb.

My usual late puzzle find. A Wednesday from February 21, 2007 by the great Elizabeth C. Gorski. Three theme answers in that one, each straightforwardly clued. WHOSYOURDADDY DOWAHDIDDYDIDDY OLDFUDDYDUDDY Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/21/2007&g=20&d=A Oh.. and that first answer led me to think of an old joke and a possible clue answer combination (never been in a puzzle). "Father from Indiana?" HOOSIERDADDY I'm done. ....

Star Wars did me in. bABBA sounded like a plausible character, and bARS are places to tip. How disheartening to learn I knew the answer without the reveal. Shoulda woulda coulda. An otherwise good time!
Don't usually check on this after completing a crossword, but since so many answers didn't make sense, I had to. Quite the eye opener.
I had a lot of fun with this one. A lot of the clues were first rate. Well done Adam ‚Äì looking forward to your next one

I don't have Thursday tension - I have Thursday anticipation, Thursday excitement! I look forward to whatever challenge may be waiting.

Terrific Thursday puzzle! Thanks for the challenge.

One thing I appreciated about Deb is that she never - or rarely - put the word "rebus" in a puzzle column where the puzzle in question did not contain a rebus. If I'm stuck on a puzzle I often search for the word in the accompanying column to determine if there is a rebus. Easy way to get that information without getting any other hints. Hopefully her colleagues follow suit.

It was a fun Thursday, but I had to take a break before completing the SW corner. When I returned a few hours later, my progress was where I left off, but the timer was reset to zero. This seems to be happening more often lately and I hope someone can look into it.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve built in failsafes!‚Äù they announce, SNUBbing the TEST footage. A few DAMNEDLIES for some EVAGREEN. All this horror to bypass cleaning up after UMAMIBOMBS.

An enjoyable Thursday puzzle for me, just a couple of look-ups needed, not bad.

I wonder if anyone else confidently put BOARD for 4A, thinking it was to do with chess, only to have to remove it when it became obvious it was wrong? I felt so clever when I entered it - and so stupid when I realised what the correct answer was! üôÑ
Went quick for me, but very fun.

Pretty shocked to learn that the constructor used AI to create this puzzle (though, it definitely confirms my suspicions on some past puzzles). ChatGPT and all AI is a blight, a total wreck on the environment, and a marker of lazy (yes, LAZY) puzzle-making. Yall will defend it, stay mad. I don‚Äôt care how much or little someone used AI to create their puzzle. It shouldn‚Äôt be allowed and NYT standards should be higher. All for a middling puzzle. Pass.

Very disappointed that today‚Äôs puzzle was created with AI. All of the environmental impacts aside, it is unbecoming of such a monumental American newspaper to allow the use of this ‚Äútool‚Äù that plagiarizes and steals from artists with no accountability.

This puzzle felt inelegant and just "off" to me, so coming to find out the constructor used AI is no surprise. Yuck. Please, stop doing that. 

Also, working on this puzzle on a Pixel phone, it seems really weird to call an IPAD an alternative. It just isn't.

Thursday is my favorite puzzle day, but not today. The tedious trivia and fill that seemed to mug for the hipness camera was both boring and exhausting and the theme while cute seemed pedestrian. I guess it's another cultural difference between us Poles and Americans. We don't overuse the word "love".

We have noun "mi≈Ço≈õƒá" and the verb "kochaƒá": both mean "love". The old Polish verb for "to love" was "mi≈Çowaƒá". Another verb became popular with time, while the noun derived from the old verb remained in use. We reserve both terms for truly special relationships with people and animals. One may "kochaƒá" one's spouse, child, puppy, or one's closest, dearest friend. But we don't "kochaƒá" puzzles, cars, casual friends, etc. I suppose our verb "uwielbiaƒá" ("to adore" would be the closest equivalent) may serve as your "love" when used regarding things one likes very much.

"Lubiƒá" is our "to like" but we use it differently than you do. A single instance of something is not something to "lubiƒá". "Lubiƒô p≈Çywaƒá" ("I like to swim") is fine, but I would never say "Lubi≈Çem mojƒÖ wczorajszƒÖ wycieczkƒô nad jezioro" ("I liked yesterday's trip to the lake"). Generally, when describing individual instances of stuff I like, I'd say something like: "Podoba≈Ço mi siƒô" ("I enjoyed [it]"), "To by≈Ço fajne" ("That was neat"), or "Spoko" ("Cool").

It's funny how French and Spanish handle "like" and "love" quite differently.

French has no verb "to like."  Aimer is to love.  So they often say "J'aime ce film."  "J'adore ce film."  To soften it a bit, to make it more like "to like," they say "J'aime bien ce film."

In Spanish, "I love you" is "Te amo," but to love a movie is "Me encanta la pel√≠cula."  To simply like the movie, you'd say, "Me gusta la pel√≠cula."  So to love a person, you use a direct verb construction, but to love or like a thing, you use a roundabout construction meaning "it enchants me" or "it pleases me."  To like a person, you can say "Me cae bien," which means literally "He/she falls well to me."

Even though I am a gamer and I know the concept of S-tier very well, I was confused by ELITE being the answer.

Most commonly, "tiers" in gaming refer to the in-game power of particular character "builds". In many games, the character you control gets a choice of many skills, but you can't pick them all - you have to make a choice, because you usually have less "skill points" to distribute" than there are skills to choose from. Also, characters receive equipment from defeating in-game challenges - weapons, armor, and the like. 

An S-tier character is one with the build and equipment providing the best in-game performance.

The progressions is as follows: S-tier, A-tier, B-tier, C-tier, D-tier, E-tier, F-tier. I suppose it's related to the American grading system, for the most part.

Effectively, S-tier characters are likely to make the best progress in a game, but the characters themselves are not the game's "elite". If anything, some *players* may be considered a game's elite, yet not necessarily for playing S-tier characters. The most respected gamers manage to outperform others even though they do *not* in fact play S-tier characters. In one of the games I used to enjoy, a person played a character who had no gear equipped, at all, and yet me managed to beat all the content. He truly was among the elite. There was another person who defeated challengers designed for groups of 10 or 25 people - solo. But it was about personal skill, not S-tier characters.

It's easy, really. Have you watched or read "The Lord of the Rings"? Along the way Frodo receives the magic ring, the mithril shirt, a magic sword, magic elven food - he is making progress as an in-game character would, recieving gear (and some skills) as he godes deeper into the "content".

The basic premise of many action games is that you start with a character clad in rags and only able to perform basic attacks with basic weapons. As you progress, you learn new skills and acquire equipment. By the end of the adventure, you are an unstoppable powerhouse, looking epic and being able to single-handedly defeat a couple of dragons as you use the other hand however you enjoy most.

Enjoy this learning opportunity :D

Well, the fate of characters with subpar builds (of the lower tiers) depends on how competitive the environment of a particular game is, and how fun the game is when playing a subpar character.

For example, in the quite popular if flawed action modern game Diablo IV, the most rewarding content is only really accessible to the most powerful characters, and thus going for a C-F tier build locks the gamer out from experiencing everything the game has to offer.

However, in Diablo II, an interation of the same franchise from 25 years ago, niche builds were quite fun and rewarding to play. I was deep into gaming theorycrafting back then (that is, working out how to best use a game's mechanics to have the most fun - math was involved! The horror!), and I designed a build for the Amazon character that definitely was not S-tier, but which provided me with unbelievable fun - my heroine shot a zillion arrows a second, speeding across the game's world like a bat out of hell. It was so awsome!

Not all games are about fighting. The ones with build tiers usually are though.

Some games do involve fighting but put in a moral context that shows violence for what it really is. The acclaimed game The Last of Us (made into a series by HBO) did that to great effect. Each of the two characters I controlled had to fight for his or her life, but there was no glory in it, only terror and and sadness.
